intro: Chaenostoma hispidum, commonly known as the hairy waterwheel, is a flowering plant native to parts of Asia, particularly China and Japan. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive leaf shapes and often edible roots. The plant is characterized by its basal rosette of hairy, lance-shaped leaves and produces small, greenish-white flowers in late summer. It thrives in moist, shady environments such as woodland floors and stream sides. Its common name reflects the hairy texture of its leaves and the wheel-like arrangement of its flowers.
